claim.text: The Passive House standard...specifies a different threshold: a maximum heating demand of 15 kWh/m² per year
claim.claim: Passive House standard specifies maximum heating demand of 15 kWh/m² per year

results.summary: The Passive House standard does specify a maximum heating demand of 15 kWh/m² per year as one of its core certification requirements.
results.detail: The Passivhaus standard, developed by the Passivhaus Institut in Darmstadt, Germany, has five key criteria, one of which is that the space heating energy demand must not exceed 15 kWh per square meter of treated floor area per year. This is a foundational and widely-documented requirement of the standard. The same limit applies to cooling demand in applicable climates.

claim.text: At -30°C, an R-22 wall with an interior setpoint of 21°C produces a temperature gradient of 2.3°C per R-value
claim.claim: R-22 wall produces temperature gradient of 2.3°C per R-value with -30°C exterior and 21°C interior

results.summary: The claim is mathematically correct based on standard thermal physics calculations.
results.detail: The temperature gradient per R-value is calculated as total temperature difference divided by total R-value. With a 51°C temperature difference (21°C - (-30°C)) across an R-22 wall, the gradient is 51/22 = 2.318°C per R-value, which rounds correctly to 2.3°C. This follows directly from the definition of R-value as thermal resistance and Fourier's law of heat conduction.
sources: Mathematical calculation based on thermal physics principles and R-value definition

claim.text: The interior surface of that wall hovers around 15°C
claim.claim: Interior surface of R-22 wall measures approximately 15°C when exterior is -30°C and interior setpoint is 21°C

results.summary: The calculation for an R-22 wall with ideal conditions yields ~19-20°C interior surface temperature, not 15°C, but thermal bridging effects could reduce this to 15°C in some areas.
results.detail: Using standard heat transfer calculations for R-22 walls (3.87 m²K/W) with interior film resistance of R-0.68, the interior surface temperature would be approximately 19-20°C under the stated conditions. The 15°C figure may represent surface temperatures at thermal bridges (studs) where effective R-value is lower, or may assume different film coefficients. The claim is physically plausible for a worst-case scenario but overstates typical surface temperature depression.
sources: ASHRAE Fundamentals handbook thermal transmission calculations
